One thing I do when practicing, is note how long has elapsed and add minute markers to the speaker notes at key stages of my talk. Then, as I present I can sense check my progress against my planned timing.

Replying to @BenedekGagyi 2018-04-24 10:31
@BenedekGagyi @Jack_Franklin @alexnmoldovan @thekitze @jsheroes I prefer conferences to set the talk duration they feel appropriate for the audience and format of the day, and then ask speakers to prepare content to fit that. I cut a 45 minute talk to fit 30 mins at #jsheroes. 45 would not have worked there (I ran over by 2.5 minutes üòü)

  • Permalink

Replying to @philhawksworth 2018-04-24 10:24
@Jack_Franklin @BenedekGagyi @alexnmoldovan @thekitze @jsheroes I'd never cut a speaker short of their allotted time due to previous schedule slippage. But I would cut Q&A, and give them a heads up *before* they speak if time had become tight and they need to be sure to finish on time. (which should go without saying anyway)
  • Permalink
  • Twitter
Replying to @Jack_Franklin 2018-04-24 10:21
@Jack_Franklin @BenedekGagyi @alexnmoldovan @thekitze @jsheroes Keeping to time is one of the biggest causes of anxiety for me when giving a talk. Particularly a new talk. This is one of the reasons I always practice my talks standing up, out loud, and timed. You feel dumb doing that alone in your kitchen, but it helps.

Replying to @philnash 2018-04-23 08:01
@philnash Gzipping and caching is done at the CDN level for you. The thing that first pursuaded me to try @Netlify over GH pages was a desire to control caching headers. Netlify's defaults are already great, but you can also take control if you prefer. Hint: https://t.co/Re1E3LtmKh

Replying to @_phzn 2018-04-23 07:15
@_phzn @philnash @Herschel_R @DKundel @Netlify @glitch @jsunconf @jekyllrb Very. You can do all of this on the free plan (and much besides). The number of free form submissions each month is limited, but scales elastically. The limit on monthly bandwidth is so high you'd need to be a *beast* to reach it. Hooks, notifications, rollbacks etc - all free.

Replying to @stefanjudis 2018-04-23 00:21
@stefanjudis @nuxt_js @contentful @Netlify You are safe to play with this. The only thing you can hurt is your own deploy. It is not advertised widely due to the complexity inherent in managing your own caching mechanics, which would likely generate a lot of support requests from people getting unexpected deploy results.
  • Permalink
  • Twitter
Replying to @stefanjudis 2018-04-23 00:09
@stefanjudis @nuxt_js @contentful @Netlify I recently discovered this undocumented ability, which may be useful! See the gulp file for where the build cache gets used. Difficulty comes in managing your caching. Netlify can't help you there, so you'd be on your own if you need to debug it. https://t.co/Yu4Usfw3OQ

Replying to @JackPrior_Cleo 2018-04-22 21:05
@Jack_RedCat @thekitze It depends on what you mean by "finish". Even after many dozens of hours researching, writing, designing, and practicing a talk, I don't consider it finished. Final fine-tuning is standard. The only reasons to need it advance are trust or preloading for display. Neither is good.
  • Permalink
  • Twitter
Replying to @alexnmoldovan 2018-04-22 20:50
@alexnmoldovan @Jack_RedCat @thekitze Even if I've given a talk before, I don't like to "freeze" it by sending slides in advance. The ability to tune it during final run-throughs (often the night before), or update with latest info is crucial to me. And being able to respond to, or echo other speakers feels valuable.
